speaker: A
speech: H J Ministry of Community Development Amendment number one

speaker: A
speech: We have twenty five minutes Mr Abdullah Tarmugi

speaker: B
speech: Sir I beg to move that the total sum to be allocated for H J of the main estimates be reduced by one hundred dollars

speaker: B
speech: Mr Chairman Sir in any country there will be families and individuals whose standard of living fall below others because of their low incomes

speaker: B
speech: In Singapore Sir we do not see the crippling poverty that exists in some countries

speaker: B
speech: In slums in the streets begging hustling others

speaker: B
speech: Ours is more subtle but it nevertheless lurks behind the doors of our rented flats

speaker: B
speech: Official estimates put the number of low income families at thirty eight thousand

speaker: B
speech: This is defined as those families whose incomes fall below the minimum household expenditure level of about five hundred eleven dollars for the family of four people

speaker: B
speech: Some of these families Sir are further disadvantaged by chronic and multiple problems in the family thus putting the children at risk

speaker: B
speech: Children Sir are inevitably caught in the poverty of their environments not only economically but also emotionally and socially

speaker: B
speech: These families need our help

speaker: B
speech: That question is who is to help them

speaker: B
speech: My TPC Sir states categorically that we do not subscribe to welfare state model as found in many countries in the west

speaker: B
speech: Apart from the government the community and the families themselves will have to work in concert to address the problems of low income families

speaker: B
speech: But still we believe that government will have to play a leading role in setting the tone of this tripartite co-operation in setting the rules in providing the basic infrastructure and in creating the atmosphere where the community will be motivated to help the families to be motivated and the families themselves to improve

speaker: B
speech: In this context Sir let me touch on the question of subsidies

speaker: B
speech: The GPC goes along with the government that mindless injections of subsidies into welfare or those which merely finance consumption should not be encouraged not entertained

speaker: B
speech: But Sir subsidies which seek to improve those who receive them into becoming more self-reliant and more independent should not be ruled out altogether

speaker: B
speech: Indeed government should not shy at granting subsidies which aim at these objectives

speaker: B
speech: They are needed and they are they also serve as an encouragement to others in the community to come forward and help

speaker: B
speech: Can the Minister therefore elaborate in this House the government's approach to social welfare and to helping the needy in our midst

speaker: B
speech: What kinds of assistance is it prepared to render to those families and how is it encouraging VWOs or Voluntary Welfare Organizations and the community

speaker: B
speech: Sir I beg to move

speaker: A
speech: Question is that the total sum to be allocated for H J of the main estimates to be reduced by one hundred dollars Mr Das

speech: Mr Chairman Sir

speech: I've two cuts

speech: Can I take them

speaker: C
speech: Mr Chairman Sir as for my first cut I will just direct one question to the Minister that is what is the government doing to enhance sports performance in general

speaker: C
speech: And in particular with the forthcoming South-east Asian Games to be staged in Singapore nineteen ninety three

speaker: C
speech: Are there any special programs to improve our haul of golds during these game

speaker: C
speech: Sir I move on to my next cut which is which is recognition for national sportsmen

speaker: C
speech: Mr Chairman Sir Singapore has in the fifties and sixties produced world class sportsmen

speaker: C
speech: To name a few well like Wong Peng Soon in badminton Ong Poh Lin badminton Ismail Maja badminton Tan Ow Liang weightlifting Neo Choo Kok swimming

speaker: C
speech: In the eighties and nineties one world class sportsman which we have produced possibly Mr Ang Peng Siong

speaker: C
speech: And uh no other name comes to my mind

speaker: C
speech: Why is this so

speaker: C
speech: Especially when we have better facilities better and more modern facilities now than in the fifties and sixties

speaker: C
speech: The reason I believe may be Sir that sports or talent in sports is not given its due recognition in Singapore

speaker: C
speech: Sportsmen give their best part of their career or age say from sixteen or in the case of swimmers even younger go up to sixteen to twenty four

speaker: C
speech: and then they fade away with no guarantee of a secure livelihood

speaker: C
speech: and there are of course other pressures

speaker: C
speech: Other talent be it academic arts I believe has been looked after reasonably well and this is not the case for sports

speaker: C
speech: Sir if we want our standard to improve then I believe something should be done

speaker: C
speech: Not everything should be done by the government but I believe government can lead the way and this can be strongly followed by the private sector

speaker: C
speech: Sir when Ang Peng Siong wins a gold medal it brings joy and pride to all Singaporeans especially when the Majulah Singapura is played

speaker: C
speech: When Fandi scores a goal fifty thousand Singaporeans roar in ecstasy

speaker: C
speech: For all these what do they get

speaker: C
speech: Ang Peng Siong now works in a club and advertises for Fab

speaker: C
speech: Sir I think the best of our sportsmen with talent must be nurtured and looked up

speaker: C
speech: Something is being done for our footballers right now

speaker: C
speech: and I think the FAS should be congratulated

speaker: C
speech: and I think more will be done in the near future

speaker: C
speech: Sir government particularly the Ministry of Defence together with private sector companies could help to nurture our talent in sports by guaranteed guaranteeing them a certain amount of livelihood

speaker: C
speech: and at the same time allowing them to continue to excel in the sports of their choice

speaker: C
speech: I hope Sir the Ministry of Community Development and the real Minister for Sports to look into this aspect

speaker: C
speech: Thank you

speaker: D
speech: Mr Chairman Sir

speaker: D
speech: I would like to support everything that Mr Chandra Das has said

speaker: D
speech: Sir for some reason we do not do very well in sports when we compete internationally

speaker: D
speech: I can understand that for a long time now we have been motivated by a need to succeed economically and that's laudable

speaker: D
speech: But we don't really have to compromise on that principle or objective

speaker: D
speech: There there is a group of people in Singapore very athletically inclined and who for some reason are not inclined towards studies

speaker: D
speech: and then don't make it to the university or other tertiary institutions

speaker: D
speech: If we don't give them incentives they're not likely to continue to play the games that they excel in with the result that they don't do well in life either in seeking a job

speaker: D
speech: and they don't exploit their sporting talents to the maximum

speaker: D
speech: Now then you therefore what you have is this group of people who are who don't do well in life and at the same time Singapore loses out on this pool of talent

speaker: D
speech: We've done economically we have concentrated on the arts

speaker: D
speech: We have need reaching for other ideals now

speaker: D
speech: I would urge the government to pay more attention to sports not only because the SEA Games is around the corner but because sports has a unique way of bringing people together

speaker: D
speech: I've said this before

speaker: D
speech: We can do so much better in getting Singaporeans to be passionate about our own country than by National Day events or by Orchard Road Swings big parties that we have

speaker: D
speech: These events are contrived to get Singaporeans together and to feel something for the country

speaker: D
speech: But there is a there is a way we can do this without having to spend millions of dollars

speaker: D
speech: And this is by encouraging our best sportsmen

speaker: D
speech: Those who are not inclined to pursue a career or to to take their studies further to concentrate their talents where they have them on the field

speaker: D
speech: For example football

speaker: D
speech: my colleague has said fifty thousand people are cheering

speaker: D
speech: No doubt a lot of them have other motivations

speaker: D
speech: They've got money on the game perhaps

speaker: D
speech: But there is this other group

speaker: D
speech: A huge majority who derive including me a tremendous amount of satisfaction and pleasure when we win

speaker: D
speech: and when you cheer you're cheering for Singapore and everybody identifies with the country for once

speaker: D
speech: There is a lot to be said about government taking the lead in setting aside a few jobs for the athletically inclined so that they can attend to their jobs from nine a.m. to three p.m. and then get out to the fields and concentrate on their sporting talents

speaker: D
speech: Build a great team in soccer in any other sport and get out there and compete internationally

speaker: D
speech: And if the government takes the lead the private sector will follow

speaker: D
speech: If we don't do that we'll never get anywhere in sports

speaker: D
speech: Sport is a unifying force we should concentrate on it

speaker: D
speech: Thank you Sir

speaker: E
speech: Thank you Mr Speaker

speaker: E
speech: Sir first of all I'd like to thank my uh three colleagues who've spoken up on the first cut

speaker: E
speech: Sir Mr Tarmugi has asked about what is the government's approach to those in need

speaker: E
speech: He has stated very clearly that the GPC does not subscribe to a welfare state

speaker: E
speech: That the members do not subscribe to just throwing money at the situation

speaker: E
speech: Sir the government's approach to social welfare is the many helping hands approach involving a partnership between government and the various civic community and welfare organizations

speaker: E
speech: Sir social welfare issues are difficult issues to deal with in any society

speaker: E
speech: Long term vision and perseverance are necessary and it require a painstaking effort

speaker: E
speech: And the results only show up many years later

speaker: E
speech: Similarly welfare assistance programs which go wrong are very difficult to unravel

speaker: E
speech: We've seen many countries in which this has happened

speaker: E
speech: They started off with very good intentions but end up only aggravating the problems instead of solving them

speaker: E
speech: For example many countries have unemployment benefits

speaker: E
speech: Very generous ones to help those who are temporarily unemployed

speaker: E
speech: What happened is that all these programs instead ended up encouraging people to stay unemployed

speaker: E
speech: In America the welfare programs started off also with very good intentions with very manageable budgets

speaker: E
speech: Today social security and welfare is the largest single item in the US federal budget taking up more than one third its budget

speaker: E
speech: We therefore are on good grounds in being very careful

speaker: E
speech: Sir our focus in our social welfare programs is to help the needy get back on their own two feet

speaker: E
speech: Tax payers' money goes only into programs which are designed to motivate and help them to become independent rather than to dampen their drive to be independent

speaker: E
speech: Sir our experience shows that giving money for example through our rents and utilities uh scheme alone is not adequate

speaker: E
speech: We had let me quote a case

speaker: E
speech: We had a case of a thirty eighty thirty eight year old divorced lady with two schooling children who are temporarily on the rents rent and utilities assistance scheme for six months

speaker: E
speech: She was first working as a night-shift uh worker because she thought that that way she can help look after her children in the day-time

speaker: E
speech: But she was not earning enough money

speaker: E
speech: And also because after working late at night she's really too tired in day-time to help to look after the children

speaker: E
speech: So she left and got a part-time job as a cleaner

speaker: E
speech: It paid even less

speaker: E
speech: As a result she was in arrears in her uh PUB bills and in her HDB rental payments

speaker: E
speech: So HDB referred her case to the Council of Social Services which administers the RUAS scheme the Rent and Utilities Assistance scheme

speaker: E
speech: Vouchers were then given to her to help her tide over pay her financial difficulties

speaker: E
speech: But over and above that a social worker from the Asian Women's welfare association helped her to look for another job which paid her more and at the same time helped her to spend more time with her children

speaker: E
speech: She was given counselling on how to budget how to manage her time

speaker: E
speech: and the association also arranged tuition for her son

speaker: E
speech: As a result she managed to manage her financial her funds better

speaker: E
speech: and uh she requested to take off to be taken off the RAUS scheme after six months <X>
